prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB130603B
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Currently there is a great interest in the nature of the short-GRB progenitors, which are believed to be neutron (NS) star mergers, since they might represent the ultimate target for the upcoming generation of gravitational wave observatories. Observational data show that about 2/3 of all short-GRB host galaxies are starforming galaxies, among which a notable fraction might even undergo a starburst. The latter suggest that the NS-NS merger population might span a wide range in ages, reaching from billions donw to millions of years. If some short-GRB progenitors are indeed member of a young stellar population, they should have been exploded close to star-forming regions. Find this out is the goal of this proposal based on a high-resolution imaging of a selected number of nearby short-GRB host galaxies in the ALMA band 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our purpose we can make use of the standard correlator set up.

All our targets are below a redshift of z=0.5. At this redshift 1 arcsec corresponds to 6 kpc projected distance. Assuming a neutron star (NS) binary with a space velocity of 100 km/s, it will move 100 pc / Myr. If we can resolve 1 kpc, we might be able to state with certainty the distance between the position of the optical transient and any hot spot in the submm band (due to a star-forming region) to better than 1 kpc. If we find such cases, this might strongly suggest a physical relation between the star-forming region and the short-burst progenitor, i.e., support the idea that it was born in this recent starburst.

All our targets are below z=0.5 and all are detected in the WISE bands. Our data suggest that we might see the hosts at a flux density of 100 microJy in band 6. We propose to use band 6 as a best compromise between sensitivity and atmospheric transmission issues. To achieve a detection above 3 sigma we ask for an rms of 30 microJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Currently there is a great interest in the nature of the short-GRB progenitors, which are believed to be neutron (NS) star mergers, since they might represent the ultimate target for the upcoming generation of gravitational wave observatories. Observational data show that about 2/3 of all short-GRB host galaxies are starforming galaxies, among which a notable fraction might even undergo a starburst. prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
